title: 105_hr1507
content: The "Hunger Has a Cure Act of 1997" amends the Food Stamp Act of 1977 to adjust standard deductions annually based on changes in the Consumer Price Index. The "Hunger Has a Cure Act of 1997" adjusts excess shelter deductions and vehicle allowances under the Food Stamp Act of 1977. SEC. 4 of the "Hunger Has a Cure Act of 1997" amends the vehicle allowance in the Food Stamp Act of 1977 by adjusting the amount to $5,000 starting from October 1, 1997, and annually thereafter based on changes in the new car component of the Consumer Price Index. Section 6(o) of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to change the requirements for receiving food stamp benefits. The amendment also includes provisions for an enhanced employment and training program under Section 16(h)(1) of the Act. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include provisions for employment and training programs, with $100,000,000 reserved annually for State agencies from 1998 to 2002. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include provisions for employment and training programs, with $100,000,000 reserved annually for State agencies from 1998 to 2002. The amendment includes eligibility criteria for individuals to receive food stamp benefits and participate in programs to satisfy requirements. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include provisions for employment and training programs, with funds allocated to State agencies. State agencies must use a specified amount of funds for the benefit of similar individuals as determined by the Secretary. SEC. 6. LEGAL IMMIGRANTS. Protecting legal immigrants who have been in the United States for at least 5 years, and those who become disabled after entry, by amending eligibility for food stamp benefits under the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. The eligibility for food stamp benefits under the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to protect qualified aliens who are under 18 years of age or over 75 years of age and have been legal permanent residents of the United States for at least 5 years. Additionally, legal immigrants who become disabled after entering the United States are also eligible for food assistance. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to protect legal immigrants who become disabled after entry. This includes changes to the Food Stamp Act of 1977 for certain aliens. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 protects legal immigrants who become disabled after entry, but this does not apply to aliens who entered the United States before August 22, 1996. The Congress recommends allocating $45,000,000 for emergency food assistance in fiscal year 1998 under the Emergency Food Assistance Act of 1983. Additionally, Congress supports full funding for the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children. The Congress should allocate $76,000,000 for the WIC program in fiscal year 1997 and $4,008,000,000 for fiscal year 1998 to support an increase in participants. Adequate funding is also recommended for the Summer Food Service Program for Children. SEC. 9 amends the National School Lunch Act to increase funding for the Summer Food Service Program for Children to $2.23. SEC. 10 provides outreach and start-up funding for school breakfast and summer feeding programs. The Child Nutrition Act of 1966 is amended to expand the school breakfast program nationwide, promoting participation through marketing and public education efforts. The Child Nutrition Act of 1966 is amended to expand the school breakfast program nationwide by providing language-appropriate materials and information to school boards and public officials. Each State educational agency is required to promote the benefits and availability of the program, especially in schools with a high percentage of low-income families that do not currently participate. The Secretary is required to report to specific committees on efforts to increase school participation in the breakfast program. The Secretary will receive $5,000,000 annually for startup and expansion costs, to be distributed competitively to State educational agencies. State educational agencies in multiple States will receive funds to assist eligible schools with starting or expanding school breakfast programs and service institutions with initiating or expanding summer food service programs for children. These payments are additional to what State agencies are entitled to under other sections of the National School Lunch Act. State educational agencies must submit a plan to the Secretary to receive payments for initiating or expanding school breakfast programs. Preference is given to agencies with state laws requiring program expansion and significant resources for program implementation. The Secretary provides preference to States with low participation in summer food service programs for children or those without such programs, to receive payments for program expansion. The Secretary gives preference to States with low participation in summer food service programs for children or those without such programs to receive payments for program expansion. States must submit a plan to expand the programs, including providing technical assistance and funding to service institutions, and utilizing significant public or private resources for the expansion. The Secretary will recover and reallocate any unused funds to other States in a timely manner. The Secretary allows States to apply annually for assistance under this subsection. States must give preference to eligible schools and service institutions with the greatest need for a school breakfast program or summer food service program. Expenditures for the maintenance of these programs shall not be reduced due to payments received. The term 'service institution' refers to an institution or organization that agrees to operate a school breakfast program or summer food service program for a period of at least 3 years, with a significant percentage of children from low-income families attending. The term 'summer food service program for children' refers to a program authorized by section 13 of the National School Lunch Act. SEC. 11. RESTORATION OF ``FOURTH MEAL'' UNDER CHILD AND ADULT CARE FOOD PROGRAM. Amends the National School Lunch Act to allow for two meals and two supplements or three meals and one supplement.
